A soprano specialised in complex, ornamented melody
A soprano who has extended her upper range beyond the usual range of a soprano
A soprano whose voice, while normally of lyric weight and fluidity, can be pushed to a more forceful weight
The resonant clarity of an operatic singer’s voice
A tenor voice capable of a slightly higher range of sustainable notes than usual
A vocal register immediately above the modal voice range
Falsetto, sung using the usual techniques of modal voice register
A male singer, castrated so as to be able to sing soprano (now sung by women, conventional countertenors, or sopranisti)
Originally, a trained musician; later, a castrato or female singer
A forceful voice, between the lyric and dramatic in weight
